content:
How about posting the exact messes you get, verbatim. My guess on almost no information is that it is unlikely to have anything to do with Thunderbird and everything to do with how you configured it long ago and changes with the server that make those old configurations invalid.

But we know nothing of the provider that is rejecting the mails, and recent changes with that provider, like the ones that have occurred with Spectrum.

SO I am reduced to googling the error "[C20]: message blocked" and the results returned indicate the error may originate with an ISP support company mailchannels. https://support.mailchannels.com/hc/en-us/articles/202223160-Fixing-the-550-5-7-1-CS-Message-blocked-error (only on their web site did google find an entry with the [C20 part of the error message)

SO this may well be a misconfiguration by your internet service provider of their mail servers or a long standing misconfiguration of Thunderbird that they are now detecting and refusing to accept. If you are sending from a single mail account, my initial guess is you need to read the mailchannels document and perhaps talk to your ISP.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Tried to add a signature? That is the most common occurrence of folk complaining about indecipherable gibberish in their new messages. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/signatures#w_signatures-stored-in-files

They have done something like chosen to add a signature from a file and linked to something like a word document, but I am sort of guessing as without images to identify what machine language means to you I have to stay very generic.

creator: Fjoerfoks

content: There is software you can install to convert the folder to individual messages, but there is an easy online approach: - rename the folders to have the .mbox suffix, e.g., inbox.mbox - in browser, open this site: https://products.aspose.app/email/conversion/mbox-to-eml - upload and convert each of the folders. the site will download as zip files - unzip the downloaded zip files and you will have each message stored with the .eml suffix. - to read them, start thunderbird - if menu bar isn't showing, press alt key and then select view>toolbars and tick menu bar. That will keep it viewable. - now, click File>Open>Saved message and select one of the saved eml files
creator: davidsk

content: The problem is Norton trying to intercept your secure connection to the server. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1448251 which is the same issue.
creator: christ1

content: You are still protected from viruses by Defender's other protection features. Since the real-time scanner is still turned on it will scan all the files and attachments in case you attempt to open or save them to disk. It will alert you if there is any infection. A malicious attachment just sitting in your Inbox does not impose a threat.
creator: christ1

content: Your screenshot shows the Google authentication prompt for your Gmail account. This is legitimate, and not a scam. Make sure you allow cookies in Thunderbird. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20

content: Please review to be sure of where they are missing from. Thunderbird's addressbook is retained on your computer, and I think Yahoo's is maintained online. Deleting one would not delete the other. If you deleted from the Thunderbird addressbook, only a backup will restore it.

content: Puzzling. Regardless, posting a screenshot of your incoming server settings may cause someone here to have suggestions. Not receiving any feedback at all is most unusual. It's as though google is not even being contacted. Do you use a VPN? Any antivirus software? Possibly a firewall is blocking? Maybe something is intercepting the request and that could be the problem, as thunderbird is quite good at giving feedback when received.

content: Here are some steps for that: - locate a post where the individual has responded. - click their name on the responses author line, which will be in bold - that takes you to the individual's profile, which has a link to all of their responses.

content:
Changed isp and email completely, and wanted to change both server name and user name.

Don't mess with your existing account. Create a new account in Thunderbird for the new server with the new credentials. Make sure to give it a unique name.
creator: christ1

content:
Thanks for your tips, but that is an awful lot of work compared to what I did even. - checkboxes here and there - a lot of text to fill in - remove and account and have old maildatabase left - assign new account to same database

I only had to change domain on three places, mail was the same.

I think looking through how lost focus on fields work instead. - I did plenty pre- and post-processing on focus() event and it can be done better. - just set a flag if leaving a field is changed - and process which changed fields as you get focus() on other fields below - then execute restart thingy

Just how I would do it...

I have almost 20 years of emails on 6 accounts in this install. So want minimum work changing ISP. New accounts will be used as continued same account as previous keep same history data.
